segments.text: Right, yeah, this was, I believe it was in 79 when Charlie Holland and I got together with Bob Walker, who was director of development here at A&M, still active, and we formed the Lindsay Lectures Committee, and we raised about $30,000 from the former students in order that we could bring in

top lectures in chemical engineering, and our real purpose was trying to get the department to be better known, because at that time the department had become reasonably strong, but it was still pretty much unknown throughout the North and East.
And so we deliberately targeted all the chemical engineers that were members of the National Academy of Engineering, for example, to bring them in here.
for a lecture so they would at least know where we were and who we were.

But that was really the first committee of our outstanding former students, and it's the forerunner of the committee we have now that's actually called a, it's called an industrial advisory committee.
The Lindsay Lecturers Committee was the forerunner of that, and it was sort of the first group of students, too, that went out to try to help us raise money.
And then later, we used this group to raise more major money.
We raised about, in total, about $250,000.
later, but this was into the early 80s.
And that's what set up the C.D.
Holland Professorship that's held at Ray Anthony now.
And also as part of that, there's the Brunner Barnes Graduate Assistantship, and there's another, I can just call it Chemical Engineering Alumni Graduate Fellowship.
And that was back in the days when at Texas A&M, if you raised money from outside sources, the board of directors would match it.
So those monies were all matched back for university money.
That's good.
The department really has done a good job in what I can tell.
Building an industry connection, using the industry connection,
And it's complimenting everybody.
It's complimenting everyone.
OK, that's really good to know.
If you were going to suggest a striking difference or a character of Holland's style as opposed to Newton's, would you agree with that or not?
Well, no, I worked very well with both of them.
Of course, when I first came, Doc Winsley was in the latter part of his tenure as department head, and of course I was just a young professor.
But I did almost immediately take on a lot of the odd jobs in the department.
And that was Charlie Holland's relief, because Charlie was way behind writing research papers and doing a lot of other things.
So when Charlie became head, the style is totally different.
And I have one document in here that I
I wrote up for Charlie Holland's retirement that says some things about Charlie.
Charlie's way of writing the department was a little different in that Charlie really liked to write textbooks.
Being head of the department, I don't think, was Charlie's great ambition.
And he was quite good at it.
But Charlie would get up at 3 o'clock every morning and write on textbooks until about 7 and would come in here.
He liked to have 7 o'clock classes, which the students didn't appreciate.
But Charlie was definitely a very early morning guy.
And then by the afternoon, Charlie would have to go to all those damn department head meetings, and you name it.
And by that time, it was evening for Charlie, and he could halfway sleep through them, which was just exactly part of his plan.
Then he would go home, and he would be in bed bait upon.
So anyway, that's the way Charlie ran things.
And I became...
I think after a few years, I became, well, Charlie's right-hand man, or maybe his hatchet man.
But anyway, and so I started doing a lot of things that department heads often do.
I became in charge of hiring all the faculty, which I did for a long time.
I think I hired, the last time I counted, I still had hired 13 of the present 25, but almost all the, quote, older guys here, I think I hired.
And that was another period where we started to hire, we hired a lot of people.
And in about, it could be off by a year, but in about 1975,
76, probably.
In 75, I hired Dick Hall or Ken Hall here.
But then Charlie said, you've got to hire five people in one year, and I about went berserk.
I didn't think that could be done.
But I did hire three people.
I hired Ralph Light, Jim Holsey, and Charlie Glover.
And those three all worked out extremely well.
Ralph White's now department head at South Carolina, so he did leave A&M about three years ago, but they've all worked out.
And then later I hired some people I shouldn't have, because I was trying to hire too many people.
We were expanding very fast there in the late 70s.
Our student population had gone completely out of hand.
As a matter of fact, when I came back from sabbatical, I had a sabbatical at Imperial College in London from 1971 to 1972.

When I came back from London, our student population was already getting out of hand, so one of the things I did in 1973, 1974, and 1975 and there, I brought in professors from England just to come here and teach for a year, because the salary structure in England was so terrible that
We could pay them far more money.
It still wasn't that much money.
And they'd come in and teach three courses.
And we were just trying to keep our heads above water, because we were faced with a tremendous number of students.
And I think at one time, we actually got up to 1,400 undergraduates.
And we were still a faculty that was around 12 people.
And it was just getting out of hand.
So Charlie actually gave me almost parts of his job.
Of course, this was all done under mutual agreement, but as Charlie and I laughed about this often, I told him, well, if you
If you ever disagree with me on a major policy, I'll quit."
So, I mean, you understand, you know, I do have to have your support, and, you know, if I'm going to do these jobs.
Well, he said, I like to designate, to delegate my authority, you know.
Well, Charlie was, he was really very good about that.
And, of course, Charlie was very, you know, good at keeping the faculty happy and, you know, being, talking to them.
But Charlie really didn't like a lot of the day-to-day operation and administration of the department.
He didn't enjoy that.
He liked to talk to people.
He's a very extroverted person.
We did a lot of things by committee.
And I also started, I'm sure of the
exact date, but started the tenure and promotion committee in that.
That was, I think, it may have been in the early 80's.
Right.
No, that's further back.
Sorry about that.
Yeah, we started in 1974.
I started as first chairman and all that.
I'm chairman of it again, just this year.
Congratulations.
Again.
Congratulations.
Been away from it for a while.
25 years later.
And we did hire, at that time, a number of quite good people, too.
We later hired Ted Watson, hired Drago Bucher here, and Iden Aukerman, also, who's now the social department head.
He's also had a very good career.
But yeah, we've hired quite a number of good people.
Several of them have left to become department heads at other schools.
Who is playing?
Yes, that is almost a story within itself.
And let me provide it, because I'm probably one of the few people.
In fact, I'm probably the only person here that can provide the story.
I'm trying to make it reasonably brief.
But Dan Pham took a PhD at MIT.
And he was also one of the early people that I hired.
And Dan is technically a genius.
I mean, really a bright guy.
But anyway, Dan is, to say the least, a little abrasive.
And he's a classic New York City boy, perhaps, but not to offend anybody.
And I've always, myself, I sort of like that.
But Dan did not get along with anybody else here too well.
And we used to go over, Fred Benson would have us all come over once a year for sort of a review and just to chat with the dean.
And I got along very well with Fred, who's another one of my really favorite people.
And so Charlie Holland always would send me over right after Flam to try to repair the damage.
And I remember the first time this happened, I walked into Fred Benson's office and he said,
He said, Eubank, I've really just gotten an earful.
That young man just told me that I had been running the college completely wrong here, and he gave me a lot of ideas how to get myself straight down and run this college a whole lot better.
So anyway, we finally got Flamm to resign, because it got to the point where
He was having major problems with, first of all, with all the students.
The students didn't like him, and with the faculty.
He basically just wasn't getting along with anybody, and it was partly because he liked to argue.
And he considered that a way of life, and his wife was a professor over in the psychology department.
And so anyway, and they argued all the time too, and it was just sort of their way of having fun.

But it was not always appreciated here, and so Dan resigned finally, and I told him, and I didn't know that this was going to be processed, but I said, you ought to go work for somebody like Bell Labs and let them put you off in a corner where you can do research and don't have to interact with other people.
Well, he went to work for Bell Labs.
And now, Flam is a very famous person.
Oh, is that right?
Yeah.
He later was really the first guy to invent...
This is in making chips for computers, like electronic chips, semiconductors.
And Dan...
is really the father of what is called anisotropic etching, which is where you go in with anisotropic.
It's A-N and then isotropic.
Let me tell you what it means.
It's where you go in and you want to etch out a square corner.
If you just put in a chemical like hydrochloric acid, it'll etch, but it'll etch like in a sphere.
It'll etch equally in sort of all directions.
That's just natural.
He developed the use of radio frequency plasma to shoot a plasma beam onto the device or onto the silicon or dope silicon and then
it would make a square corner.
So all the stuff you see on your computer chips are, you know, those things have all got these square corners.
And so that etching was all developed at Bell Labs.
And if you look at the original research papers, the first name was Phlam.
And I was, because I'm involved in plasmas, I was at a meeting just a year and a half ago, International Plasma Chemistry meeting,
And I talked to some of the people who were also on those papers who had worked with him, and they said, well, you know, it was difficult to work with him, but they had, and that had great success.
And Dan is now a consultant, actually, to the chemical engineering department at Berkeley, at UC Berkeley.
But I've also talked to some people out there, and they said, well, you know, he
You have to keep him at arm's length, and we don't dare put him in the classroom, because he really is still pretty much, he has not mellowed.
I thought he might mellow with years, like some of us, but apparently he hasn't mellowed too much.
But anyway, he did something really wonderful.
Some people don't care.
They do.
They do not.
If he tried to stay here, it never would have worked.
It would have never worked, though.
Well, I better let you go.
But one thing I might come back and ask you about later, Bill, is that you couldn't tell me there is a plan.
Right.
I'm probably going to go off over the more lasting, and I'm going to talk to Ray.
This is something I didn't start.
I mean, for sure.
I started the...
roll chapter of Omega Chi Epsilon, which was the National Chemical Engineering Honor Society in 1970 here at A&M.
Again, I won't exactly say that I started it.
At that time, I was the chief faculty advisor to Tau Beta Pi, which was the engineering honor society.
But it takes into account everybody here in engineering.
And some of the chemical engineering students in Tau Beta Pi came to me and said they wanted to form a separate
honor just for chemical engineers.
Because I could never get elected to office here in the Tall Bay to Pine, because they were always outvoted because they were more mechanical civil engineers.
And so we formed the Roe chapter.
And it later became the largest chapter in the country.
And I was advisor until about six years ago.
And then Ray Anthony took it for about four years.
And when did that start?
It started in 1970.
And now Omega Chi Epsilon, the national honorary, has grown.
We were about 18.
We now have about 60 chapters in Omega Chi.
And as of the last year, I'm the national president of Omega Chi.
And we are still growing at the rate of about five chapters a year.
And we now have 20,000 total members, and we're initiating about 1,000.
I just signed 1,000 certificates over the Christmas holidays.
So we're initiating about 1,000 people every year at about 20 campuses across the country.
Is yours a one-year tenure for 96, 97?
No, actually, it's a four-year tenure.
stuck with it, I think, for about three more years, but it's a rather nice job being president because we have a secretary-treasurer who's at Kansas State who does all the work.
I mean, as of the National Society, I mostly go to meetings and figure heads, so it's quite pleasant.
But I wanted to bring that up because
That's something that did start here.
And I'm still trying to reactivate the Alpha chapter, because this was founded at the University of Illinois in the 1920s.
And later, Illinois became inactive for the chapter.
So I'm trying to get them back.
But it's a real fine honorary.
All right.
